Read this sample answer to the writing task you looked at in earlier exercises. Complete the composition by choosing the word or phrase which best fits each gap.
Writing Task 2

section.p: Most cities now have pedestrian precincts and from time to time cities are in the news because cars have been temporarily banned from the centre to reduce pollution. However, no town council has yet had the courage to completely prohibit private motor vehicles from entering the city centre. There are several reasons why I believeI supportI am in favour of this should be done.

The most important reason isI am opposed toA good exampe of this is pollution from car exhausts, which damages people's health causing respiratory diseases such as asthma and bronchitis. At the same time, traffic fumes attack the stonework of historic monuments and buildings, while the vibrations from passing vehicles damage their foundations. This, for instanceI agreeI am against, has happened to many old cathedrals in Europe.

A second reasonThe most important reasonA final reason why I am in favour ofconvinced thatof the opinion that cars being banned is in order to reduce the noise pollution from traffic, which forces people to keep their windows permanently closed and may cause psychological problems including stress and depression among people living in busy streets.

A further reasonThe most important reasonThe final reason is that most cities were not designed for motor traffic. A good example of this isPersonally, I feel thatI am strongly of the opinion that the historic centre of Valencia, which has narrow streets and few facilities for parking. As a result, traffic moves very slowly and there are frequent traffic jams. Beautiful buildings are spoilt by always having cars parked in front of them and pretty streets become unpleasant due to permanent traffic congestion and exhaust fumes.

Finally, I am sureI strongly supportI am opposed to the idea that if cars were banned, people would find other more pleasant ways to move around cities. For exampleA good example of this isA case in point is, they would walk or use bicycles as these would once more become safe and enjoyable activities within the city. This in turn would bring about a general improvement in people's health.

In conclusion, therefore, I strongly support the ideaI am in favour ofOn the grounds that traffic should be banned from city centres, as this would enable people to rediscover cities as pleasant and healthy places to live.
1. 'support' and 'in favour of' need to be followed with a noun or gerund.
2. 'I am opposed to'. You can be opposed to an idea, or something that people do, but not a 'thing' such as 'pollution'.
'A good example of this is'. An example of what?
3. The writer is giving an example here.
4. 'The most important reason'. This was given in the previous paragraph.
'A final reason'. The writer has more than two reasons.
5. This needs to be followed with a verb phrase, 'convinced that cars should be banned', for example.
6. 'The most important reason' was dealt with earlier.
'The final reason'. The writer has other points to add yet.
7. The writer is giving an example here.
8. 'support' needs to be followed with a noun or gerund.
'I am opposed to the idea'. In fact, the writer supports the idea of banning cars from city centres.
9. Notice the punctuation in this sentence.
10. 'in favour of' needs to be followed with a noun or gerund.
'On the grounds'. This expression isn't used to introduce an opinion, but to give reasons why the writer holds that view.
